Ruptured spleen_1:
Patient Description 1: 
A 35-year-old male patient, with a history of participating in contact sports, presented with a persistent, sharp pain in the upper left stomach, which he rated as 7/10 in intensity. The pain is accompanied by tenderness upon palpation of the same area. Furthermore, the patient reported left shoulder pain. On examination, he exhibited signs of confusion, lightheadedness, and dizziness. The patient denied any history of liver disease or blood cancers. There is a possibility of a forceful blow to the stomach due to the patient's sporting activities, which could be a contributing factor to the observed symptoms.
Ruptured spleen_2:
Patient Description 2:
A 25-year-old female patient, with a recent history of mononucleosis, presented with a throbbing pain in the upper left stomach area, which she described as 6/10 in intensity. Tenderness was noted upon palpation of the affected area. The patient also reported left shoulder pain. She exhibited episodes of confusion, lightheadedness, and dizziness. There is a known history of mononucleosis, which may have led to the enlargement of the spleen, rendering it more susceptible to injury.
Ruptured spleen_3:
Patient Description 3:
A 40-year-old male patient, who works in a high-risk occupation, presented with a sharp, constant pain in the upper left stomach, rated at 8/10 in intensity. Tenderness was noted upon palpation of the affected area. The patient also complained of left shoulder pain. Additionally, he displayed symptoms of confusion, lightheadedness, and dizziness. Given the nature of the patient's occupation, there is an increased risk of sustaining an injury to the left side of the body, including the spleen. No history of liver disease or blood cancers was reported. These contextual factors are crucial in the diagnostic assessment of the observed symptoms.
